xccdf:Benchmark.xccdf:title: USGCB: Guidance for Securing Microsoft Internet Explorer 7
xccdf:Benchmark.xccdf:description: This guide has been created to assist IT professionals in effectively securing systems with Microsoft Internet Explorer 7 installed.
xccdf:Benchmark.xccdf:notice: Do not attempt to implement any of the settings in this guide without first testing them in a non-operational environment. NIST assumes no responsibility whatsoever for its use by other parties, and makes no guarantees, expressed or implied, about its quality, reliability, or any other characteristic. NIST would appreciate acknowledgement if the document and template are used.
xccdf:Benchmark.xccdf:front-matter: The Federal CIO council created the Technology Information Subcommittee (TIS) at the direction of OMB to govern, among other federal activities, the FDCC iniatitive. The TIS, based on federal agency input, selects platforms and applcations for federal implementation. The TIS also is the Change Control Board (CCB) for configuration settings. As stated in the Federal CIO Council Memo to federal agencies, "The USGCB settings replace the Federal Desktop Core Configuration (FDCC) settings and provide the recommended security baselines for Information Technology products widely deployed across the agencies."

xccdf:Profile.xccdf:title: United States Government Configuration Baseline version 1.2.3.1
xccdf:Profile.xccdf:description: This profile represents guidance outlined by the United States Government Configuration Baseline for a desktop system with Microsoft Internet Explorer 7 installed.

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Introduction
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: This guide has been created to assist federal agencies in effectively securing systems with Microsoft Windows Internet Explorer 7 based on OMB United States Government Configuration Baseline recommendations.Under the direction of OMB and in collaboration with DHS, DISA, NSA, USAF, and Microsoft, NIST has provided the following baseline to help agencies test, implement, and deploy the Microsoft Windows Internet Explorer 7 United States Government Configuration Baseline (USGCB) baseline. The United States Government Configuration Baseline (USGCB) is an OMB-mandated security configuration.Please refer to the USGCB home page for additional information. http://USGCB.nist.gov

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: USGCB Other Settings
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: USGCB has identified the following additional controls that must be checked in order to verify compliance.

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Core Policy
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: The following are some additional settings for Microsoft Internet Explorer 7

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Disable "Configuring History" - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This setting specifies the number of days that Internet Explorer keeps track of the pages viewed in the History List. The delete Browsing History option can be accessed using Tools, Internet Options and General tab.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Disable Changing Automatic Configuration Settings - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This Disable Automatic Install of Internet Explorer components setting prevents Internet Explorer from automatically installing components.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Do Not Allow Users to enable or Disable Add-Ons - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: The Do not allow users to enable or disable add-ons policy setting allows you to manage whether users have the ability to allow or deny add-ons through Manage Add-ons. If you configure this policy setting to Enabled, users cannot enable or disable add-ons. This item is disabled.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Make proxy settings per-machine (rather than per-user) - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: The Make proxy settings per - machine (rather than per-user) setting ensures proxy settings for all users of the same computer are the same.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Prevent participation in the Customer Experience Improvement Programs - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting prevents users from participating in the Customer Experience Improvement Program (CEIP).

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Prevent performance of First Run Customize settings - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting prevents performance of the First Run Customize settings ability and controls what the user will see when they launch Internet Explorer for the first time after installation of Internet Explorer.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Security Zones: Do Not Allow Users to Add/Delete Sites - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: The Security Zones: Do not allow users to add/delete sites setting prevents users from adding or removing sites from security zones. A security zone is a group of Web sites with the same security level.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Security Zones: Do Not Allow Users to Change Policies - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: The Security Zones: Do not allow users to change policies setting prevents users from changing security zone settings. A security zone is a group of Web sites with the same security level.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Security Zones: Use Only Machine Settings - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Applies security zone information to all users of the same computer. A security zone is a group of Web sites with the same security level. If you enable this policy, changes that the user makes to a security zone will apply to all users of that computer.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Turn Off Crash Detection - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: The Turn off Crash Detection policy setting allows you to manage the crash detection feature of add-on management in Internet Explorer.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Turn Off Managing Phishing Filter - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows the user to enable a phishing filter that will warn if the Web site being visited is known for fraudulent attempts to gather personal information through "phishing."

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Turn Off the Security Settings Check Feature - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting turns off the Security Settings Check feature, which checks Internet Explorer security settings to determine when the settings put Internet Explorer at risk.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Allow active content from CDs to run on user machines - Local Computer - variable
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Allow Active Content from CD's to Run on User Machine - Local Computer - variable

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Allow Install OnDemand (Internet Explorer) - Local Computer - variable
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Allow Install OnDemand (Internet Explorer) - Local Computer - variable

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Allow Software to Run or Install Even if the Signature is Invalid - Local Computer - variable
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Allow Software to Run or Install Even if the Signature is Invalid - Local Computer - variable

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Allow Software to Run or Install Even if the Signature is Invalid - Local Computer - variable
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Allow Software to Run or Install Even if the Signature is Invalid - Local Computer - variable

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Allow Third-Party Browser Extensions - Local Computer - variable
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Allow Third-Party Browser Extensions - Local Computer - variable

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Check for Server Certificate Revocation - Local Computer - variable
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Check for Server Certificate Revocation - Local Computer - variable

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Check for signatures on downloaded programs - Local Computer - variable
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: Check for Signature on Downloaded Programs - Local Computer - variable

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Allow Active Content from CDs to Run on User Machine - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether users receive a dialog requesting permission for active content on a CD to run. If you enable this policy setting, active content on a CD will run without a prompt.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Advanced Page

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Allow Software to Run or Install Even if the Signature is Invalid - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Microsoft ActiveX controls and file downloads often have digital signatures attached that vouch for both the file's integrity and the identity of the signer (creator) of the software. Such signatures help ensure that unmodified.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Advanced Page

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Allow Third-Party Browser Extensions - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether Internet Explorer will launch COM add-ons known as browser helper objects, such as toolbars.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Advanced Page

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Automatically Check for Internet Explorer Updates - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether Internet Explorer checks the Internet for newer versions.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Advanced Page

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Check for Server Certificate Revocation - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether Internet Explorer will check revocation status of servers' certificates.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Advanced Page

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Check for signatures on downloaded programs - Local Computer - variable
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether Internet Explorer checks for digital signatures (which identifies the publisher of signed software and verifies it hasn't been modified or tampered with) on user computers before downloading executable programs.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Advanced Page

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Intranet Sites: Include all network paths (UNCs) - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting controls whether URLs representing UNCs are mapped into the local Intranet security zone. If you enable this policy setting, all network paths are mapped into the Intranet Zone.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Site to Zone Assignment List
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Computer-wide, rather than per-user, assignment of sites to zones for Internet Explorer should be enabled or disabled as appropriate.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Access Data Sources Across Domains - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether Internet Explorer can access data from another security zone using the Microsoft XML Parser (MSXML) or ActiveX Data Objects (ADO).

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Allow cut, copy or paste operations from the clipboard via script - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether scripts can perform a clipboard operation (for example, cut, copy, and paste) in a specified region. If you enable this policy setting, a script can perform a clipboard operation.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Allow drag and drop or copy and paste files - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether users can drag files or copy and paste files from a source within the zone. If you enable this policy setting, users can drag files or copy and paste files from this zone automatically.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Allow Font Downloads - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether pages of the zone may download HTML fonts. If you enable this policy setting, HTML fonts can be downloaded automatically.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Allow installation of desktop items - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether users can install Active Desktop items from this zone. The settings for this option are: If you enable this policy setting, users can install desktop items from this zone automatically.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Allow script-initiated windows without size or position constraints - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage restrictions on script-initiated pop-up windows and windows that include the title and status bars. If you enable this policy setting, Windows Restrictions security will not apply in this zone.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Allow Scriptlets - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether scriptlets can be allowed. If you enable this policy setting, users will be able to run scriptlets. If you disable this policy setting, users will not be able to run scriptlets.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Allow status bar updates via script - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether script is allowed to update the status bar within the zone. If you enable this policy setting, script is allowed to update the status bar.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Automatic prompting for file downloads - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting determines whether users will be prompted for non user-initiated file downloads. Regardless of this setting, users will receive file download dialogs for user-initiated downloads.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Download signed ActiveX controls - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether users may download signed ActiveX controls from a page in the zone. If you enable this policy, users can download signed controls without user intervention.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Download unsigned ActiveX controls - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether users may download unsigned ActiveX controls from the zone. Such code is potentially harmful, especially when coming from an untrusted zone.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Initialize and script ActiveX controls not marked as safe - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage ActiveX controls not marked as safe. If you enable this policy setting, ActiveX controls are run, loaded with parameters, and scripted without setting object safety for untrusted data or scripts.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Java permissions - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage permissions for Java applets. If you enable this policy setting, you can choose options from the drop-down box. Custom, to control permissions settings individually.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Launching applications and files in an IFRAME - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether applications may be run and files may be downloaded from an IFRAME reference in the HTML of the pages in this zone.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Logon Options - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage settings for logon options. If you enable this policy setting, you can choose from the following logon options.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Loose or un-compiled XAML files - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: These are eXtensible Application Markup Language (XAML) files. XAML is an XML-based declarative markup language commonly used for creating rich user interfaces and graphics that leverage the Windows Presentation Foundation.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Navigate sub-frames across different domains - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage the opening of sub-frames and access of applications across different domains. If you enable this policy setting, users can open sub-frames from other domains and access applications from other domains.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Open files based on content, not file extension - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage MIME sniffing for file promotion from one type to another based on a MIME sniff. A MIME sniff is the recognition by Internet Explorer of the file type based on a bit signature.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Software channel permissions - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage software channel permissions. If you enable this policy setting, you can choose the following options from the drop-down box.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Turn Off First-Run Opt-In - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Turn Off First-Run Opt-In

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Turn On Protected Mode - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: The "Turn on Protected Mode" setting should be configured correctly for the Internet Zone.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Use Pop-up Blocker - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether unwanted pop-up windows appear. Pop-up windows that are opened when the end user clicks a link are not blocked. If you enable this policy setting, most unwanted pop-up windows are prevented from appearing.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Userdata Persistence - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage the preservation of information in the browser's history, in favorites, in an XML store, or directly within a Web page saved to disk.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Web sites in less privileged Web content zones can navigate into this zone - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether Web sites from less privileged zones, such as Restricted Sites, can navigate into this zone.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Allow scripting of Internet Explorer web browser control - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting controls whether a page may control embedded WebBrowser Controls via script

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Allow status bar updates via script - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether script is allowed to update the status bar within the zone. If you enable this policy setting, script is allowed to update the status bar.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Include local directory path when uploading files to a server - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting controls whether or not the local path information will be sent when uploading a file via a HTML form.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Launching programs and unsafe files - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting controls whether or not the 'Open File - Security Warning' prompt is shown when launching executables or other unsafe files.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Run .NET Framework-reliant components not signed with Authenticode - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether .NET Framework components that are not signed with Authenticode can be executed from Internet Explorer.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Run .NET Framework-reliant components signed with Authenticode - Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether .NET Framework components that are signed with Authenticode can be executed from Internet Explorer.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Java permissions - Intranet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage permissions for Java applets. If you enable this policy setting, you can choose options from the drop-down box. Custom, to control permissions settings individually.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Intranet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Java permissions - Local Machine Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage permissions for Java applets. If you enable this policy setting, you can choose options from the drop-down box. Custom, to control permissions settings individually.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Local Machine Zone

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Locked Down Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: Locked Down Internet Zone - Local Computer

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Download Signed ActiveX Controls - Locked Down Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: The "Download signed ActiveX controls" setting should be configured correctly for the Locked-Down Internet Zone.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Locked-Down Internet Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Java permissions - Locked Down Internet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage permissions for Java applets. If you enable this policy setting, you can choose options from the drop-down box. Custom, to control permissions settings individually.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Locked-Down Internet Zone

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Locked Down Intranet Zone - Local Computer

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Java permissions - Locked Down Intranet Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage permissions for Java applets. If you enable this policy setting, you can choose options from the drop-down box. Custom, to control permissions settings individually.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Locked-Down Intranet Zone

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Locked Down Local Machine Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: Locked Down Local Machine Zone - Local Computer

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Java permissions - Locked Down Local Machine - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage permissions for Java applets. If you enable this policy setting, you can choose options from the drop-down box. Custom, to control permissions settings individually.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Locked-Down Local Machine Zone

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Locked Down Restricted Sites Zone - Local Compute - Local Computer
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: Locked Down Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Java permissions - Locked Down Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage permissions for Java applets. If you enable this policy setting, you can choose options from the drop-down box. Custom, to control permissions settings individually.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Locked-Down Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Locked Down Trusted Sites Zone - Local Computer - Local Compute
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: Locked Down Trusted Sites Zone - Local Computer

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Java permissions - Locked Down Trusted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage permissions for Java applets. If you enable this policy setting, you can choose options from the drop-down box. Custom, to control permissions settings individually.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Locked-Down Trusted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Access Data Sources Across Domains - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether Internet Explorer can access data from another security zone using the Microsoft XML Parser (MSXML) or ActiveX Data Objects (ADO).

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Allow Active Scripting - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether script code on pages in the zone is run. If you enable this policy setting, script code on pages in the zone can run automatically.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Allow Binary and Script Behaviors - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage dynamic binary and script behaviors: components that encapsulate specific functionality for HTML elements to which they were attached. If you enable this policy setting, binary and script behaviors are available.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Allow cut, copy or paste operations from the clipboard via script - Restricted SitesZone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether scripts can perform a clipboard operation (for example, cut, copy, and paste) in a specified region. If you enable this policy setting, a script can perform a clipboard operation.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Allow drag and drop or copy and paste files - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether users can drag files or copy and paste files from a source within the zone. If you enable this policy setting, users can drag files or copy and paste files from this zone automatically.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Allow File Downloads - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether file downloads are permitted from the zone. This option is determined by the zone of the page with the link causing the download, not the zone from which the file is delivered.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Allow Font Downloads - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether pages of the zone may download HTML fonts. If you enable this policy setting, HTML fonts can be downloaded automatically.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Allow installation of desktop items - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether users can install Active Desktop items from this zone. The settings for this option are: If you enable this policy setting, users can install desktop items from this zone automatically.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Allow META REFRESH - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether a user's browser can be redirected to another Web page if the author of the Web page uses the Meta Refresh setting (tag) to redirect browsers to another Web page.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Allow script-initiated windows without size or position constraints - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage restrictions on script-initiated pop-up windows and windows that include the title and status bars. If you enable this policy setting, Windows Restrictions security will not apply in this zone.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Allow status bar updates via script - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether script is allowed to update the status bar within the zone. If you enable this policy setting, script is allowed to update the status bar.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Automatic prompting for file downloads - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting determines whether users will be prompted for non user-initiated file downloads. Regardless of this setting, users will receive file download dialogs for user-initiated downloads.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Download signed ActiveX controls - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether users may download signed ActiveX controls from a page in the zone. If you enable this policy, users can download signed controls without user intervention.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Download unsigned ActiveX controls - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether users may download unsigned ActiveX controls from the zone. Such code is potentially harmful, especially when coming from an untrusted zone.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Initialize and script ActiveX controls not marked as safe - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage ActiveX controls not marked as safe. If you enable this policy setting, ActiveX controls are run, loaded with parameters, and scripted without setting object safety for untrusted data or scripts.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Java permissions - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage permissions for Java applets. If you enable this policy setting, you can choose options from the drop-down box. Custom, to control permissions settings individually.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Launching applications and files in an IFRAME - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether applications may be run and files may be downloaded from an IFRAME reference in the HTML of the pages in this zone.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Logon Options - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage settings for logon options. If you enable this policy setting, you can choose from the following logon options.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Loose or un-compiled XAML files - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: These are eXtensible Application Markup Language (XAML) files. XAML is an XML-based declarative markup language commonly used for creating rich user interfaces and graphics that leverage the Windows Presentation Foundation.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Navigate sub-frames across different domains - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage the opening of sub-frames and access of applications across different domains. If you enable this policy setting, users can open sub-frames from other domains and access applications from other domains.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Open files based on content, not file extension - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage MIME sniffing for file promotion from one type to another based on a MIME sniff. A MIME sniff is the recognition by Internet Explorer of the file type based on a bit signature.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Run .NET Framework-reliant components not signed with Authenticode - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether .NET Framework components that are not signed with Authenticode can be executed from Internet Explorer.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Run .NET Framework-reliant components signed with Authenticode - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether .NET Framework components that are signed with Authenticode can be executed from Internet Explorer.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Run ActiveX controls and plugins - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether ActiveX controls and plug-ins can be run on pages from the specified zone. If you enable this policy setting, controls and plug-ins can run without user intervention.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Script ActiveX controls marked safe for scripting - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether an ActiveX control marked safe for scripting can interact with a script. If you enable this policy setting, script interaction can occur automatically without user intervention.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Scripting of Java Applets - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether applets are exposed to scripts within the zone. If you enable this policy setting, scripts can access applets automatically without user intervention.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Software channel permissions - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage software channel permissions. If you enable this policy setting, you can choose the following options from the drop-down box.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Turn Off First-Run Opt-In - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Turn Off First-Run Opt-In

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Turn On Protected Mode - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: The "Turn on Protected Mode" setting should be configured correctly for the Restricted Sites Zone.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Use Pop-up Blocker - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether unwanted pop-up windows appear. Pop-up windows that are opened when the end user clicks a link are not blocked.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Userdata Persistence - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage the preservation of information in the browser's history, in favorites, in an XML store, or directly within a Web page saved to disk.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Web sites in less privileged Web content zones can navigate into this zone - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether Web sites from less privileged zones, such as Restricted Sites, can navigate into this zone.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Allow scripting of Internet Explorer web browser control - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting controls whether a page may control embedded WebBrowser Controls via script

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Allow Scriptlets - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether scriptlets can be allowed. If you enable this policy setting, users will be able to run scriptlets. If you disable this policy setting, users will not be able to run scriptlets.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Include local directory path when uploading files to a server - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting controls whether or not the local path information will be sent when uploading a file via a HTML form.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Launching programs and unsafe files - Restricted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting controls whether or not the 'Open File - Security Warning' prompt is shown when launching executables or other unsafe files.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Trusted Sites Zone - Local Computer - Local Compute

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Java permissions - Trusted Sites Zone - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows you to manage permissions for Java applets. If you enable this policy setting, you can choose options from the drop-down box. Custom, to control permissions settings individually.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Trusted Sites Zone

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Periodic Check for Updates - Local Computer
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: Periodic Check for Updates to Internet Explorer and Internet Tools - Local Computer

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Turn Off changing the URL to be displayed for checking updates to Internet Explorer and Internet Tools - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This policy setting allows checking for updates for Internet Explorer from the specified URL, included by default in Internet Explorer.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Settings\Component Updates\Periodic check for updates to Internet Explorer and Internet Tools

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Turn Off Configuring the Update Check Interval (In Days) - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: This setting specifies the update check interval. The default value is 30 days. If you enable this policy setting, the user will not be able to configure the update check interval. You have to specify the update check interval.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Settings\Component Updates\Periodic check for updates to Internet Explorer and Internet Tools

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Internet Explorer Processes - Consistent Mime Handling - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Internet Explorer uses Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions (MIME) data to determine file handling procedures for files received through a Web server.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Security Features\Consistent Mime Handling

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Mime Sniffing Safety Feature - Local Computer
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: Mime Sniffing Safety Feature - Local Computer

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Internet Explorer Processes - Mime Sniffing Safety Feature - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: MIME sniffing is the process of examining the content of a MIME file to determine its context - whether it is a data file, an executable file, or some other type of file.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Security Features\Mime Sniffing Safety Feature

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: MK Protocol Security Restriction - Local Computer
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: MK Protocol Security Restriction - Local Computer

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Internet Explorer Processes - MK Protocol Security Restriction - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: The MK Protocol Security Restriction policy setting reduces attack surface area by blocking the seldom used MK protocol. Some older Web applications use the MK protocol to retrieve information from compressed files.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Security Features\MK Protocol Security Restriction

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Protection From Zone Elevation - Local Computer
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: Protection From Zone Elevation - Local Computer

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Internet Explorer Processes - Protection From Zone Elevation - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Internet Explorer places restrictions on each Web page it opens that are dependent upon the location of the Web page (such as Internet zone, Intranet zone, or Local Machine zone).

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Security Features\Protection From Zone Elevation

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Internet Explorer Processes - Restrict File Download - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: In certain circumstances, Web sites can initiate file download prompts without interaction from users. This technique can allow Web sites to put unauthorized files on users' hard drives if they click the wrong button and accept the download.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Security Features\Restrict File Download

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Scripted Window Security Restrictions - Local Computer
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: Scripted Window Security Restrictions - Local Computer

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Internet Explorer Processes - Scripted Window Security Restrictions - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Internet Explorer allows scripts to programmatically open, resize, and reposition various types of windows. Often, disreputable Web sites will resize windows to either hide other windows or force you to interact with a window that contains malicious code.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Security Features\Scripted Window Security Restrictions

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Internet Explorer Processes - Restrict ActiveX Install - Local Computer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: The Restrict ActiveX Install\Internet Explorer Processes policy setting enables blocking of ActiveX control installation prompts for Internet Explorer processes.

xccdf:reference.dc:source: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Security Features\Restrict ActiveX Install

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Disable AutoComplete for forms
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Disable AutoComplete for forms

xccdf:reference.dc:source: User Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Disable external branding of Internet Explorer
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Disable external branding of Internet Explorer

xccdf:reference.dc:source: User Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Turn on the auto-complete feature for user names and passwords on forms
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Turn on the auto-complete feature for user names and passwords on forms

xccdf:reference.dc:source: User Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Turn off page transitions
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Turn off page transitions

xccdf:reference.dc:source: User Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Settings\Advanced settings\Browsing

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Security Patches
xccdf:Group.xccdf:description: Securing a given computer has become increasingly important. As such, it is essential to keep a host up to current patch levels to eliminate known vulnerabilities and weaknesses. In conjunction with antivirus software and a personal firewall, patching goes a long way to securing a host against outside attacks and exploitation. Microsoft provides two mechanisms for distributing security updates: Automatic Updates and Microsoft Update. In smaller environments, either method may be sufficient for keeping systems current with patches. Other environments typically have a software change management control process or a patch management program that tests patches before deploying them; distribution may then occur through local Windows Update Services (WUS) or Windows Server Update Services (WSUS) servers, which provide approved security patches for use by the Automatic Updates feature.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Security Patches Up-To-Date
xccdf:Rule.xccdf:description: Keep systems up to current patch levels to eliminate known vulnerabilities and weaknesses.

boolean_question.question_text: Does the Internet Explorer setting "Disable AutoComplete for forms" located at "User Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer" have the value Enabled?

Does the Internet Explorer setting "Disable external branding of Internet Explorer" located at "User Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer" have the value Enabled?

Does the Internet Explorer setting "Turn on the auto-complete feature for user names and passwords on forms" located at "User Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer" have the value Disabled?

Does the Internet Explorer setting "Turn off page transitions" located at "User Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Advanced settings\Browsing" have the value Enabled?

metadata.title: Computer Configuration\Network\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Features\Consistent Mime Handling\Internet Explorer Processes
metadata.description: Internet Explorer uses Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions (MIME) data to determine file handling procedures for files received through a Web server. This policy setting determines whether Internet Explorer requires that all file-type information provided by Web servers be consistent. For example, if the MIME type of a file is text/plain but the MIME sniff indicates that the file is really an executable file, Internet Explorer renames the file by saving it in the Internet Explorer cache and changing its extension. If you enable this policy setting, Internet Explorer requires consistent MIME data for all received files. If you disable this policy setting, Internet Explorer will not require consistent MIME data for all received files. If you do not configure this policy setting, Internet Explorer requires consistent MIME data for all received files.

criterion.comment: Computer Configuration\Network\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Features\Consistent Mime Handling\Internet Explorer Processes

metadata.title: User Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Disable the Reset Web Settings feature
metadata.description: Prevents users from restoring default settings for home and search pages. If you enable this policy, the Reset Web Settings button on the Programs tab in the Internet Options dialog box appears dimmed.

criterion.comment: User Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Disable the Reset Web Settings feature

metadata.title: User Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Disable AutoComplete for forms
metadata.description: This AutoComplete feature suggests possible matches when users are filling up forms. If you enable this setting, the user is not suggested matches when filling forms. The user cannot change it.

criterion.comment: User Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Disable AutoComplete for forms
User Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Disable AutoComplete for forms

metadata.title: Microsoft Internet Explorer 7 is installed
metadata.description: A version of Microsoft Internet Explorer 7 is installed.

modified.comment: Added Microsoft Windows Vista to the list of affected platforms.
Added Microsoft Internet Explorer 7 product. Removed Microsoft reference
Changed the pattern match from '^7\..*$' to '^7\.[0-9.]*$'.

contributor.organization: National Institute of Standards and Technology

criterion.comment: Internet Explorer 7 is installed

metadata.title: Allow scripting of Internet Explorer web browser control
metadata.description: This policy setting controls whether a page may control embedded WebBrowser Controls via script

criterion.comment: Computer Configuration\Network\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone\Allow scripting of Internet Explorer web browser control

metadata.title: Computer Configuration\Network\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone\Allow status bar updates via script
metadata.description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether script is allowed to update the status bar within the zone. If you enable this policy setting, script is allowed to update the status bar.

criterion.comment: Computer Configuration\Network\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone\Allow status bar updates via script

metadata.title: Include local directory path when uploading files to a server
metadata.description: This policy setting controls whether or not the local path information will be sent when uploading a file via a HTML form.

criterion.comment: Computer Configuration\Network\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone\Include local directory path when uploading files to a server

metadata.title: Launching programs and unsafe files
metadata.description: This policy setting controls whether or not the 'Open File - Security Warning' prompt is shown when launching executables or other unsafe files.

criterion.comment: Computer Configuration\Network\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone\Launching programs and unsafe files

metadata.title: Run .NET Framework-reliant components not signed with Authenticode
metadata.description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether .NET Framework components that are not signed with Authenticode can be executed from Internet Explorer.

criterion.comment: Computer Configuration\Network\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone\Run .NET Framework-reliant components not signed with Authenticode

metadata.title: Run .NET Framework-reliant components signed with Authenticode
metadata.description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether .NET Framework components that are signed with Authenticode can be executed from Internet Explorer.

criterion.comment: Computer Configuration\Network\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Internet Zone\Run .NET Framework-reliant components signed with Authenticode

metadata.title: Allow scripting of Internet Explorer web browser control
metadata.description: This policy setting controls whether a page may control embedded WebBrowser Controls via script

criterion.comment: Computer Configuration\Network\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone\Allow scripting of Internet Explorer web browser control

metadata.title: Include local directory path when uploading files to a server
metadata.description: This policy setting controls whether or not the local path information will be sent when uploading a file via a HTML form.

criterion.comment: Computer Configuration\Network\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone\Include local directory path when uploading files to a server

metadata.title: Launching programs and unsafe files
metadata.description: This policy setting controls whether or not the 'Open File - Security Warning' prompt is shown when launching executables or other unsafe files.

criterion.comment: Computer Configuration\Network\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone\Launching programs and unsafe files

metadata.title: Allow Scriptlets
metadata.description: This policy setting allows you to manage whether scriptlets can be allowed. If you enable this policy setting, users will be able to run scriptlets. If you disable this policy setting, users will not be able to run scriptlets.

criterion.comment: Computer Configuration\Network\Internet Explorer\Internet Control Panel\Security Page\Restricted Sites Zone\Allow Scriptlets
